py-tidymodels
  • py-recipes: Feature Engineering
  • View page source

py-recipes: Feature Engineering

The py_recipes package provides 51 preprocessing steps for advanced feature engineering.

Core Classes

class py_recipes.Recipe(steps=<factory>, template=None, roles=<factory>)[source]

Bases: object

Feature engineering specification.

A Recipe is a specification of preprocessing steps that can be: 1. Fitted to training data via prep() 2. Applied to new data via PreparedRecipe.bake()

Recipes ensure consistent preprocessing between training and test data, preventing data leakage.

steps

List of RecipeStep objects to apply

template

Optional template DataFrame for role inference

roles

Dictionary mapping role names to column lists

Examples

>>> # Create recipe
>>> rec = (
...     Recipe()
...     .step_normalize(["feature1", "feature2"])
...     .step_dummy(["category"])
... )
>>>
>>> # Fit to training data
>>> rec_fit = rec.prep(train_data)
>>>
>>> # Apply to test data
>>> test_transformed = rec_fit.bake(test_data)
steps: List[Any]
template: Optional[DataFrame] = None
roles: Dict[str, List[str]]
add_step(step)[source]

Add a preprocessing step to the recipe.

Parameters:

step (RecipeStep) RecipeStep to add

Return type:

Recipe

Returns:

Self for method chaining

step_normalize(columns=None, method='zscore')[source]

Normalize numeric columns.

Centers and scales numeric features using StandardScaler (zscore) or MinMaxScaler (minmax).

Parameters:

  • columns (Optional[List[str]]) Columns to normalize (None = all numeric)

  • method (str) Normalization method (zscore or minmax)

Return type:

Recipe

Returns:

Self for method chaining

Examples

>>> rec = Recipe().step_normalize(["feature1", "feature2"])
>>> rec = Recipe().step_normalize(method="minmax")
step_dummy(columns, one_hot=True)[source]

Create dummy variables from categorical columns.

Converts categorical variables to numeric using one-hot encoding or integer encoding.

Parameters:

  • columns (List[str]) Categorical columns to encode

  • one_hot (bool) Use one-hot encoding (True) or integer encoding (False)

Return type:

Recipe

Returns:

Self for method chaining

Examples

>>> rec = Recipe().step_dummy(["category", "group"])
step_impute_mean(columns=None)[source]

Impute missing values using mean.

Replaces NA values in numeric columns with the training mean.

Parameters:

columns (Optional[List[str]]) Columns to impute (None = all numeric with NA)

Return type:

Recipe

Returns:

Self for method chaining

Examples

>>> rec = Recipe().step_impute_mean(["feature1", "feature2"])
step_impute_median(columns=None)[source]

Impute missing values using median.

Replaces NA values in numeric columns with the training median.

Parameters:

columns (Optional[List[str]]) Columns to impute (None = all numeric with NA)

Return type:

Recipe

Returns:

Self for method chaining

step_mutate(transformations)[source]

Create or modify columns using custom functions.

Parameters:

transformations (Dict[str, callable]) Dict mapping column names to transformation functions

Return type:

Recipe

Returns:

Self for method chaining

Examples

>>> rec = Recipe().step_mutate({
...     "log_feature": lambda df: np.log(df["feature"] + 1),
...     "interaction": lambda df: df["x1"] * df["x2"]
... })
step_lag(columns, lags)[source]

Create lag features for time series data.

Creates lagged versions of specified columns to capture temporal patterns.

Parameters:

  • columns (List[str]) Columns to create lags for

  • lags (List[int]) List of lag periods (e.g., [1, 2, 7] for 1-day, 2-day, 7-day lags)

Return type:

Recipe

Returns:

Self for method chaining

Examples

>>> rec = Recipe().step_lag(["sales", "price"], lags=[1, 7, 30])
step_diff(columns=None, lag=1, differences=1)[source]

Create differenced features.

Computes differences between consecutive observations to make time series stationary.

Parameters:

  • columns (Optional[List[str]]) Columns to difference (None = all numeric)

  • lag (int) Period for differencing (default 1)

  • differences (int) Number of times to difference (default 1)

Return type:

Recipe

Returns:

Self for method chaining

Examples

>>> rec = Recipe().step_diff(["sales"], lag=1)
>>> rec = Recipe().step_diff(["price"], lag=7, differences=2)
step_pct_change(columns=None, periods=1)[source]

Create percent change features.

Computes percentage changes between consecutive observations.

Parameters:

  • columns (Optional[List[str]]) Columns to compute percent changes for (None = all numeric)

  • periods (int) Number of periods for change calculation (default 1)

Return type:

Recipe

Returns:

Self for method chaining

Examples

>>> rec = Recipe().step_pct_change(["sales", "revenue"])
>>> rec = Recipe().step_pct_change(["price"], periods=7)
step_rolling(columns, window, stats=None)[source]

Create rolling window statistics.

Computes statistics over rolling windows (mean, std, min, max, sum).

Parameters:

  • columns (List[str]) Columns to compute rolling stats for

  • window (int) Size of rolling window

  • stats (Optional[List[str]]) Statistics to compute (default [mean]) Options: mean, std, min, max, sum

Return type:

Recipe

Returns:

Self for method chaining

Examples

>>> rec = Recipe().step_rolling(["sales"], window=7, stats=["mean", "std"])
>>> rec = Recipe().step_rolling(["price"], window=30, stats=["min", "max"])
step_date(column, features=None)[source]

Extract date/time features from datetime columns.

Creates features like year, month, day, dayofweek, quarter, etc.

Parameters:

  • column (str) Datetime column to extract features from

  • features (Optional[List[str]])

    List of features to extract (default [year, month, day, dayofweek]) Options: year, month, day, dayofweek, dayofyear, quarter,

    week, hour, minute, is_weekend, is_month_start, is_month_end, is_quarter_start, is_quarter_end, is_year_start, is_year_end

Return type:

Recipe

Returns:

Self for method chaining

Examples

>>> rec = Recipe().step_date("date", features=["year", "month", "dayofweek"])
>>> rec = Recipe().step_date("timestamp", features=["hour", "is_weekend"])
step_pca(columns=None, num_comp=None, threshold=None)[source]

Principal Component Analysis (PCA) transformation.

Reduces dimensionality by projecting data onto principal components.

Parameters:

  • columns (Optional[List[str]]) Columns to apply PCA to (None = all numeric)

  • num_comp (Optional[int]) Number of components to keep

  • threshold (Optional[float]) Variance threshold (alternative to num_comp)

Return type:

Recipe

Returns:

Self for method chaining

Examples

>>> rec = Recipe().step_pca(num_comp=5)
>>> rec = Recipe().step_pca(["x1", "x2", "x3"], num_comp=2)
>>> rec = Recipe().step_pca(threshold=0.95)  # Keep 95% of variance
step_select_corr(outcome, threshold=0.9, method='multicollinearity')[source]

Select features based on correlation.

Removes features with low correlation to the outcome variable or high correlation with other predictors (multicollinearity).

Parameters:

  • outcome (str) Outcome column name

  • threshold (float) Correlation threshold (default 0.9 for multicollinearity)

  • method (str) Selection method - multicollinearity or outcome

Return type:

Recipe

Returns:

Self for method chaining

Examples

>>> # Remove highly correlated predictors
>>> rec = Recipe().step_select_corr("sales", threshold=0.9, method="multicollinearity")
>>> # Keep only features correlated with outcome
>>> rec = Recipe().step_select_corr("sales", threshold=0.3, method="outcome")
step_log(columns=None, base=2.718281828459045, offset=0.0, signed=False)[source]

Apply logarithmic transformation.

Parameters:

  • columns (Optional[List[str]]) Columns to transform (None = all numeric)

  • base (float) Logarithm base (default: natural log)

  • offset (float) Value added before transformation (default: 0)

  • signed (bool) If True, preserves sign (default: False)

Return type:

Recipe

Returns:

Self for method chaining

step_sqrt(columns=None)[source]

Apply square root transformation.

Parameters:

columns (Optional[List[str]]) Columns to transform (None = all numeric)

Return type:

Recipe

Returns:

Self for method chaining

step_boxcox(columns=None, lambdas=None)[source]

Apply Box-Cox power transformation.

Parameters:

  • columns (Optional[List[str]]) Columns to transform (None = all numeric)

  • lambdas (Optional[Dict[str, float]]) Optional dict of lambda parameters

Return type:

Recipe

Returns:

Self for method chaining

step_yeojohnson(columns=None, lambdas=None)[source]

Apply Yeo-Johnson power transformation.

Parameters:

  • columns (Optional[List[str]]) Columns to transform (None = all numeric)

  • lambdas (Optional[Dict[str, float]]) Optional dict of lambda parameters

Return type:

Recipe

Returns:

Self for method chaining

step_naomit(columns=None)[source]

Remove rows with missing values.

Filters out rows containing NA/NaN values in specified columns. Commonly used after creating lag features which introduce NaN at the beginning of time series.

Parameters:

columns (Optional[List[str]]) Columns to check for NAs (None = check all columns)

Return type:

Recipe

Returns:

Self for method chaining

Examples

>>> # Remove rows with any NA values
>>> recipe().step_lag(['value'], lags=[1, 7]).step_naomit()
>>>
>>> # Remove rows with NA in specific lag columns
>>> recipe().step_naomit(columns=['value_lag_1', 'value_lag_7'])

step_holiday(date_column, country='US', holidays=None, prefix='holiday_')[source]

Add holiday indicator features.

Creates binary indicators for holidays, useful for capturing holiday effects in time series models. Uses pytimetk if available.

Parameters:

  • date_column (str) Column containing dates

  • country (str) Country code for holidays (e.g., US, UK, CA)

  • holidays (Optional[List[str]]) List of specific holidays (None = all major holidays)

  • prefix (str) Prefix for created columns

Return type:

Recipe

Returns:

Self for method chaining

Examples

>>> rec = Recipe().step_holiday('date', country='US')
>>> rec = Recipe().step_holiday('date', holidays=["Christmas Day", "New Year's Day"])
step_fourier(date_column, period, K=5, prefix='fourier_')[source]

Add Fourier features for seasonality.

Creates sine and cosine features at different frequencies to capture seasonal patterns. Works with pytimetk if available.

Parameters:

  • date_column (str) Column containing dates or numeric time index

  • period (float) Period of seasonality (e.g., 365 for yearly, 12 for monthly)

  • K (int) Number of Fourier term pairs to include

  • prefix (str) Prefix for created columns

Return type:

Recipe

Returns:

Self for method chaining

Examples

>>> # Yearly seasonality with 5 Fourier pairs
>>> rec = Recipe().step_fourier('date', period=365, K=5)
>>> # Monthly seasonality
>>> rec = Recipe().step_fourier('month', period=12, K=3)
step_timeseries_signature(date_column, features=None, prefix='')[source]

Extract comprehensive time-based features from dates.

Creates 15+ time features including hour, day, month, quarter, year, day of week, weekend indicators, etc. Uses pytimetk if available.

Parameters:

  • date_column (str) Column containing dates

  • features (Optional[List[str]]) List of specific features to extract (None = all)

  • prefix (str) Prefix for created columns

Return type:

Recipe

Returns:

Self for method chaining

Examples

>>> # Extract all time features
>>> rec = Recipe().step_timeseries_signature('date')
>>> # Extract specific features
>>> rec = Recipe().step_timeseries_signature('date', features=['month', 'day_of_week'])

Create lead (future) features.

Creates features that look ahead in time, useful for prediction tasks. Works with pytimetk if available.

Parameters:

  • columns (List[str]) Columns to create leads for

  • leads (List[int]) List of lead periods (e.g., [1, 2, 7])

  • prefix (str) Prefix for created columns

Return type:

Recipe

Returns:

Self for method chaining

Examples

>>> # 1-step and 7-step ahead features

step_ewm(columns, span=10, statistics=None, prefix='ewm_')[source]

Create exponentially weighted moving (EWM) features.

Computes EWM statistics giving more weight to recent observations. Useful for capturing trends and momentum.

Parameters:

  • columns (List[str]) Columns to compute EWM for

  • span (int) Span for exponential weighting (smaller = more recent weight)

  • statistics (Optional[List[str]]) Statistics to compute (mean, std, var)

  • prefix (str) Prefix for created columns

Return type:

Recipe

Returns:

Self for method chaining

Examples

>>> # EWM mean with span of 10
>>> rec = Recipe().step_ewm(['sales'], span=10, statistics=['mean'])
>>> # EWM mean and std
>>> rec = Recipe().step_ewm(['price'], span=20, statistics=['mean', 'std'])
step_expanding(columns, statistics=None, prefix='expanding_', min_periods=1)[source]

Create expanding window features.

Computes cumulative statistics from the start to each point. Useful for running totals, cumulative averages, etc.

Parameters:

  • columns (List[str]) Columns to compute expanding stats for

  • statistics (Optional[List[str]]) Statistics to compute (mean, std, sum, min, max)

  • prefix (str) Prefix for created columns

  • min_periods (int) Minimum periods required

Return type:

Recipe

Returns:

Self for method chaining

Examples

>>> # Cumulative mean
>>> rec = Recipe().step_expanding(['sales'], statistics=['mean'])
>>> # Running total and cumulative average
>>> rec = Recipe().step_expanding(['revenue'], statistics=['sum', 'mean'])

step_vip(outcome, threshold=1.0, num_comp=2)[source]

Variable Importance in Projection (VIP) feature selection.

Calculates VIP scores from a PLS model and selects features based on threshold. VIP scores measure the importance of each variable in the projection used in a PLS model.

Parameters:

  • outcome (str) Name of outcome column (required for supervised selection)

  • threshold (float) VIP threshold for feature selection (default 1.0) Variables with VIP > threshold are kept

  • num_comp (int) Number of PLS components to use (default 2)

Return type:

Recipe

Returns:

Self for method chaining

Examples

>>> rec = recipe()
>>> rec = rec.step_vip(outcome='y', threshold=1.0, num_comp=2)
step_boruta(outcome, max_iter=100, random_state=None, perc=100, alpha=0.05)[source]

Boruta all-relevant feature selection.

Uses Boruta algorithm to identify all features that are statistically relevant to the outcome. Creates shadow features and compares real feature importance to maximum shadow importance.

Parameters:

  • outcome (str) Name of outcome column (required)

  • max_iter (int) Maximum number of iterations (default 100)

  • random_state (Optional[int]) Random seed for reproducibility (default None)

  • perc (int) Percentile of shadow feature importance to compare against (default 100)

  • alpha (float) P-value threshold for feature importance test (default 0.05)

Return type:

Recipe

Returns:

Self for method chaining

Examples

>>> rec = recipe()
>>> rec = rec.step_boruta(outcome='y', max_iter=100)
step_rfe(outcome, n_features=None, step=1, estimator=None)[source]

Recursive Feature Elimination (RFE) feature selection.

Recursively removes features and builds models to find the optimal subset. Uses model coefficients or feature importances to rank features.

Parameters:

  • outcome (str) Name of outcome column (required)

  • n_features (Optional[int]) Number of features to select (default None = select half)

  • step (int) Number of features to remove at each iteration (default 1)

  • estimator (Optional[Any]) Sklearn estimator to use (default None = LogisticRegression/LinearRegression)

Return type:

Recipe

Returns:

Self for method chaining

Examples

>>> rec = recipe()
>>> rec = rec.step_rfe(outcome='y', n_features=10)
prep(data, training=True)[source]

Fit recipe to training data.

Executes each steps prep() method sequentially, fitting parameters on the training data.

Parameters:

  • data (DataFrame) Training data

  • training (bool) Whether this is training data

Return type:

PreparedRecipe

Returns:

PreparedRecipe ready to bake new data

Examples

>>> rec = Recipe().step_normalize()
>>> rec_fit = rec.prep(train_data)
__init__(steps=<factory>, template=None, roles=<factory>)

Main Functions

py_recipes.recipe(data=None)[source]

Create a new recipe.

Parameters:

data (Optional[DataFrame]) Optional template DataFrame for role inference

Return type:

Recipe

Returns:

Empty Recipe ready for steps

Examples

>>> rec = recipe().step_normalize().step_dummy(["category"])

Selectors

Column selector functions for recipes

Provides tidyselect-style functions for selecting columns by type, role, or pattern. Inspired by tidymodels recipes::selections.

py_recipes.selectors.all_numeric()[source]

Select all numeric columns.

Returns a selector function that identifies numeric columns.

Return type:

Callable[[DataFrame], List[str]]

Returns:

Function that takes a DataFrame and returns list of numeric column names

Examples

>>> data = pd.DataFrame({'x': [1, 2, 3], 'y': ['a', 'b', 'c']})
>>> selector = all_numeric()
>>> selector(data)
['x']

Return type:

Callable[[DataFrame], List[str]]

Returns:

Function that takes a DataFrame and returns list of nominal column names

Examples

>>> data = pd.DataFrame({'x': [1, 2, 3], 'y': ['a', 'b', 'c']})
>>> selector = all_nominal()
>>> selector(data)
['y']

py_recipes.selectors.starts_with(prefix, ignore_case=True)[source]

Select columns whose names start with a prefix.

Parameters:

  • prefix (str) String prefix to match

  • ignore_case (bool) Whether to ignore case (default: True)

Return type:

Callable[[DataFrame], List[str]]

Returns:

Function that takes a DataFrame and returns matching column names

Examples

>>> data = pd.DataFrame({'temp_1': [1], 'temp_2': [2], 'other': [3]})
>>> selector = starts_with('temp')
>>> selector(data)
['temp_1', 'temp_2']

>>> selector(data)

py_recipes.selectors.matches(pattern, ignore_case=True)[source]

Select columns whose names match a regular expression.

Parameters:

  • ignore_case (bool) Whether to ignore case (default: True)

Return type:

Callable[[DataFrame], List[str]]

Returns:

Function that takes a DataFrame and returns matching column names

Examples

>>> data = pd.DataFrame({'x1': [1], 'x2': [2], 'y1': [3]})

Callable[[DataFrame], List[str]]

Returns:

Function that takes a DataFrame and returns matching column names

py_recipes.selectors.none_of(*columns)[source]

Return type:

Callable[[DataFrame], List[str]]

Function that takes a DataFrame and returns non-matching column names

>>> selector(data)
['x', 'z']
py_recipes.selectors.where(predicate)[source]

Select columns where predicate is true.

Parameters:

predicate (Callable[[Series], bool]) Function that takes a Series and returns bool

Return type:

Callable[[DataFrame], List[str]]

Returns:

Function that takes a DataFrame and returns matching column names

Examples

>>> data = pd.DataFrame({'x': [1, 2, 3], 'y': [10, 20, 30]})
>>> selector = where(lambda s: s.max() > 20)
>>> selector(data)
['y']
py_recipes.selectors.union(*selectors)[source]

Combine multiple selectors with union (OR).

Parameters:

*selectors (Callable[[DataFrame], List[str]]) Selector functions to combine

Return type:

Callable[[DataFrame], List[str]]

Returns:

Function that returns union of all selector results

Examples

>>> data = pd.DataFrame({'x': [1], 'y': ['a']})
>>> selector = union(starts_with('x'), all_nominal())
>>> selector(data)
['x', 'y']
py_recipes.selectors.intersection(*selectors)[source]

Combine multiple selectors with intersection (AND).

Parameters:

*selectors (Callable[[DataFrame], List[str]]) Selector functions to combine

Return type:

Callable[[DataFrame], List[str]]

Returns:

Function that returns intersection of all selector results

Examples

>>> data = pd.DataFrame({'x_num': [1], 'x_str': ['a'], 'y_num': [2]})
>>> selector = intersection(starts_with('x'), all_numeric())
>>> selector(data)
['x_num']
py_recipes.selectors.difference(include, exclude)[source]

Select columns from include selector but not in exclude selector.

Parameters:

  • include (Callable[[DataFrame], List[str]]) Selector for columns to include

  • exclude (Callable[[DataFrame], List[str]]) Selector for columns to exclude

Return type:

Callable[[DataFrame], List[str]]

Returns:

Function that returns difference of selectors

Examples

>>> data = pd.DataFrame({'x': [1], 'y': [2], 'z': [3]})
>>> selector = difference(all_numeric(), one_of('y'))
>>> selector(data)
['x', 'z']
py_recipes.selectors.has_role(role)[source]

Select columns with a specific role.

Note: This requires the selector to be used within a Recipe context where roles are defined.

Parameters:

role (str) Role name to filter by

Return type:

Callable[[DataFrame], List[str]]

Returns:

Function that takes a DataFrame and returns columns with role

Examples

>>> # Within a recipe context
>>> rec = recipe().update_role(['x1', 'x2'], 'predictor')
>>> rec = rec.step_normalize(has_role('predictor'))
py_recipes.selectors.resolve_selector(selector, data)[source]

Resolve a selector specification to a list of column names.

Parameters:

  • selector (Union[None, str, List[str], Callable[[DataFrame], List[str]]]) Column specification - can be: - None: select all columns - str: single column name - List[str]: list of column names - Callable: selector function

  • data (DataFrame) DataFrame to apply selector to

Return type:

List[str]

Returns:

List of column names

Examples

>>> data = pd.DataFrame({'x': [1], 'y': [2]})
>>> resolve_selector(None, data)
['x', 'y']
>>> resolve_selector('x', data)
['x']
>>> resolve_selector(['x', 'y'], data)
['x', 'y']
>>> resolve_selector(all_numeric(), data)
['x', 'y']

Examples

Basic Recipe

from py_recipes import recipe

# Create recipe
rec = (
    recipe()
    .step_normalize()  # Z-score normalization
    .step_dummy(["category"])  # One-hot encoding
)

# Prep on training data
rec_prepped = rec.prep(train_data)

# Apply to train and test
train_processed = rec_prepped.bake(train_data)
test_processed = rec_prepped.bake(test_data)

Advanced Recipe

from py_recipes import recipe
from py_recipes.selectors import all_numeric, all_nominal

# Complex preprocessing pipeline
rec = (
    recipe()
    .step_impute_median(all_numeric())
    .step_impute_mode(all_nominal())
    .step_log(["price", "income"])
    .step_normalize(all_numeric())
    .step_dummy(all_nominal())
    .step_poly(["age"], degree=2)
    .step_interact([("income", "age")])
    .step_corr(threshold=0.9)
    .step_nzv()
)

rec_prepped = rec.prep(train_data)
train_processed = rec_prepped.bake(train_data)

Time Series Recipe

from py_recipes import recipe

# Time series feature engineering
rec = (
    recipe()
    .step_lag(["sales"], lags=[1, 7, 14, 28])
    .step_diff(["sales"], lag=1)
    .step_timeseries_signature(["date"])
    .step_impute_median(all_numeric())
    .step_normalize(all_numeric())
)

rec_prepped = rec.prep(train_data)
train_processed = rec_prepped.bake(train_data)
